FeedItems.Title: Enable repeatable package restores using a lock file
FeedItems.Summary: With PackageReference, NuGet always tries to produce the same closure of package dependencies if the input package reference list has not changed. However, there are a few scenarios where it may not...

FeedItems.Title: Lock down your dependencies using configurable trust policies
FeedItems.Summary: For the past several months we have focused on various features to improve package security and trust. Around a year back, we had announced our plans on various signing functionalities that we have...

FeedItems.Title: Improved package debugging experience with the NuGet.org symbol server
FeedItems.Summary: Starting today, you can publish symbol packages to the NuGet.org symbol server. With NuGet.org as a single service provider for libraries and symbols, package authors and consumers will have a...

FeedItems.Title: Introducing Source Code Link for NuGet packages
FeedItems.Summary: NuGet.org now supports surfacing source code repository link for NuGet packages. This will enable package authors to surface both the project’s website and the source repository using the...

FeedItems.Title: NuGet.org starts repo-signing packages

FeedItems.Title: Introducing signed package submissions to NuGet.org

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remove setting "RejectPackagesWithLicense" from web.config" (#7083) at NuGet/NuGetGallery

Remove orphan registrations on user delete. 

Addresses [Deleting a user does not remove their ownership from package registrations without packages](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7197)

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Undesired functionality with lowercase 'repositorypath' in nuget.config" (#8266) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

If there is a `repositorypath` setting (lowercase 'p') in a `nuget.config` high in a directory path, it will take precedence to the packages specified from any project or solution level `nuget.config` that follow.

This becomes a problem when a user tries to modify NuGet packages and they don't know about this `repositorypath` setting somewhere in their path. As such, it will always access the wrong package even if you've correctly defined a solution-level `nuget.config`.

(tagging @mj1856, who helped discover this, thanks Matt!)

---

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):

NuGet.exe, VS UI

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):

4.9.3.5777

VS version (if appropriate): 

VS 2017

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):

Win10

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

**Please see the PR listed below for easy repro!**

1. Define a `nuget.config` in a source-level directory (i.e., `src/nuget.config`) with `repositorypath` all lowercase. Set the value to be `incorrectPackage`.

2. Define another `nuget.config` in a folder beyond (i.e., `src/TestFolder/nuget.config`) with `repositoryPath` and set the value to be `correctPackage`.

3. Make a Visual Studio solution at this level (note: this declares intent "I want the project packages to be written as this config specifies").

Hierarchy should look something like this:
```
src
- TestFolder
    - nuget.config
    - TestProject.sln
- nuget.confg
```

We expect that the `nuget.config` closest to `TestProject.sln` (with `correctPackages` defined) will be used.

4. Run the following from root: `nuget restore src\TestFolder\TestProject.sln` and see the packages are installed to `incorrectPackages` in root.

### Sample Project

https://github.com/jonnykrysh/nuget-issue

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "NuGet.CommandLine as dotnet global tool" (#8263) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm resolving various tools in a build script using `dotnet tool install`:

```ps1
dotnet tool install altcover.global --tool-path tools
dotnet tool install Codecov.Tool --tool-path tools

# ...

tools\altcover --inputDirectory=...
tools\codecov --name=...
```

(After 3.0 is released, I'll be using the beautiful and amazing https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/10288 to do the same thing.)

One of the tasks I want to do from the build script is `nuget sign`. It would be cool if this just worked:

```ps1
dotnet tool install NuGet.CommandLine --tool-path tools

tools\nuget sign -CertificateFingerprint ...
```

Instead, this prints:

```
error NU1212: Invalid project-package combination for NuGet.CommandLine 5.0.2. DotnetToolReference project style can only contain references of the DotnetTool type
The tool package could not be restored.
Tool 'nuget.commandline' failed to install. This failure may have been caused by:

* You are attempting to install a preview release and did not use the --version option to specify the version.
* A package by this name was found, but it was not a .NET Core tool.
* The required NuGet feed cannot be accessed, perhaps because of an Internet connection problem.
* You mistyped the name of the tool.
```

Would adding the package type `DotnetTool` to `NuGet.CommandLine` be possible?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Investigate signature trust and validity functional tests" (#8265) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used: NuGet API

NuGet version: dev branch

OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)): NuGet CI Pipeline

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: These are tests that fails intermitently. 

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Run a CI Build

The tests that are failing are:

- `VerifySignaturesAsync_WithExpiredPrimarySignature_ValidCountersignature_AndPrimarySignatureValidAtCountersignTime_SucceedsAsync` [permalink](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/b039c16d01170759f12fb5da4a78aba36a425779/test/NuGet.Core.FuncTests/NuGet.Packaging.FuncTest/SigningTests/SignatureTrustAndValidityVerificationProviderTests.cs#L474) Failing at line 512 (approximately)
- `VerifySignaturesAsync_WithExpiredAndUntrustedPrimarySignature_ValidCountersignature_AndPrimarySignatureValidAtCountersignTime_SucceedsAsync` [permalink](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/b039c16d01170759f12fb5da4a78aba36a425779/test/NuGet.Core.FuncTests/NuGet.Packaging.FuncTest/SigningTests/SignatureTrustAndValidityVerificationProviderTests.cs#L522) Failing at line 562 (apporximately)


## Other suggested things

Both tests fails at verifying a results list that should be empty, according to the tests.

```c#
  var resultsWithErrors = result.Results.Where(r => r.GetErrorIssues().Any());
```

Other failing builds:

- https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=2798844&view=logs
- https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=2772497&view=logs&runId=6816226&resultId=100819
- https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=2792043&view=logs&runId=6965562&resultId=100192

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Source-build patch removal for NuGet" (#8214) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Source-build has some patches that we are currently applying to your repo.  This issue tracks removing the patches.  These patches can be found at https://github.com/dotnet/source-build/tree/release/3.0/patches/nuget-client.

Patches that have the responsibility "Repo" and the Disposition "Incorporate" are patches that we believe are valid source-build fixes that should be moved into your repo.  Please let us know if these don't seem like good patches.  Any changes with the responsibility "source-build" is something that we plan to keep going forward or integrate in another way - please also let us know if you think there may be problems with those patches.

Patch name | Type | Disposition | Responsibility | Notes
-- | -- | -- | -- | --
nuget-client/0001-Update-Reference-Assemblies-package-to-get-net472-ve.patch | Build | Incorporate | Repo | Believe this was fixed upstream already.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue ""dotnet restore" fails if "nuget" folder doesn't exist" (#8264) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @gthvidsten on Wednesday, June 26, 2019 11:58:14 AM_

## Steps to reproduce

I cloned a repo, but restore of NuGet packages (`dotnet restore`) failed with the following message:

> C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\2.2.101\NuGet.targets(114,5): error : The local source 'C:\ClonedRepo\nuget' doesn't exist. [C:\ClonedRepo\src\SomeProject\src\SomeProject.csproj]

I manually created `C:\ClonedRepo\nuget` and ran `dotnet restore` again, and now it worked just fine.

## Expected  behavior

`dotnet restore` should create the `nuget` folder if it doesn't exist.

## Actual behavior

`dotnet restore` fails because it can't find non-existing folder

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet.CommandLine as dotnet global tool" (#8263) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I'm resolving various tools in a build script using `dotnet tool install`:

```ps1
dotnet tool install altcover.global --tool-path tools
dotnet tool install Codecov.Tool --tool-path tools

# ...

tools\altcover --inputDirectory=...
tools\codecov --name=...
```

(After 3.0 is released, I'll be using the beautiful and amazing https://github.com/dotnet/cli/issues/10288 to do the same thing.)

One of the tasks I want to do from the build script is `nuget sign`. It would be cool if this just worked:

```ps1
dotnet tool install NuGet.CommandLine --tool-path tools

tools\nuget sign -CertificateFingerprint ...
```

Instead, this prints:

```
error NU1212: Invalid project-package combination for NuGet.CommandLine 5.0.2. DotnetToolReference project style can only contain references of the DotnetTool type
The tool package could not be restored.
Tool 'nuget.commandline' failed to install. This failure may have been caused by:

* You are attempting to install a preview release and did not use the --version option to specify the version.
* A package by this name was found, but it was not a .NET Core tool.
* The required NuGet feed cannot be accessed, perhaps because of an Internet connection problem.
* You mistyped the name of the tool.
```

Would this be a possibility in the future?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature Request] Disable caching for local/file system feeds" (#8251) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
For our builds we are using a local nuget feed to get dependencies from.

This local feed gets updated for every build - the version number of the packages do not always change.

Since nuget prefers the local cache (.nuget) over the file system source - we need to clear that cache manually all the time to make this work.

It would be nice if caching could be disabled on a per feed basis (especially for local / file system based feeds).

This is for SDK style / package reference based projects.

Build script: https://github.com/IdentityServer/IdentityServer4/blob/master/build.ps1

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget list & add commands are being deprecated in 5.0" (#34) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Tracking Issue(s):
* Deprecate ambiguous nuget.exe commands in 5.0 [#7753](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7753)
  * Deprecate nuget.exe add command [#7923](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7923)
  * Rename nuget.exe list to nuget.exe search [#7912](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7912)

The following commands are being deprecated because these are cause of confusion due to their nomenclature and/or other related commands that already exist:
* [`nuget list`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-list): Currently displays a list of packages from a given source
  * This will be replaced by an equivalent command **`nuget search`** which will be later enhanced with more capabilities as we make progress with or [search improvements](nvmd got it: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6371​​​​​​​).
* [`nuget add`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-add): Currently adds a specified package to a non-HTTP package source (a folder or UNC path) in a hierarchical layout, wherein folders are created for the package ID and version number. 
  * This will be replaced by overloading **`nuget push`** command.

> These commands will be deprecated i.e. there will be a warning on usage of these commands in 5.0 so that in future releases these commands can be discontinued.
